Fields.DialogueText: That last battle was tough! The Morganas almost crossed our T!
Ja, Kapitän, but with a properly timed Gefechtskehrtwendung, we were able to turn our entire fleet 180° to avoid the T crossing!
The crew hated it when you made them practice all those Gefechtskehrtwendung drills in the middle of the night, but it finally came in handy when we needed to pull one off in battle.
Die Mannschaft may complain that I'm too strict, Kapitän, but I have my reasons. One needs a well-trained Mannschaft to dominate the enemy.

Fields.MenuText: I agree, Scheer! "Train hard, fight easy," as they say!
Training is essential, but we also need to balance it with rest to keep morale high.
You're driving the crew too hard, Scheer. You're just one step away from breaking the crew and causing a mutiny!

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad we agree, Kapitän. If the sailors sit idle, they will only grow soft and lazy.
Rest only encourages boredom and laziness, Kapitän. A busy crew with work to do will naturally have high morale.
Sailors are like Schäferhunde, Kapitän. They are happiest when their master gives them a job to do.
I have been collecting my observations of das Schiff und die Mannschaft in meinem Notizbuch, Kapitän. I have a long list of changes that must be made to improve our efficiency and effectiveness.
Hmm... I suppose I'm always open to suggestions on how to improve things around here.
These are not suggestions, Kapitän - these changes must be implemented as soon as possible for the sake of the mission.
I'm the ship's captain, Scheer, so you can't really order me--
*ALARM*
We will get started with the changes immediately after we destroy these Nixen, Kapitän. Gefechtsstationen!
Hey, I'm the one who gives orders around here! Battlestations!
@BATTLE
I have a long list of changes, Kapitän, so I will start with der Ersten.
I suppose there's no stopping you with this list of yours, so I'm happy to listen and consider any reasonable ideas you have to improve things.
Excellent. Als Erstes ist die Flak dran, Kapitän.
What's wrong with our anti-aircraft guns?
They are inadequate in both quantity and power to deal with the increasing threat of aerial attacks, Kapitän. We must improve them immediately.

Fields.MenuText: That's true! In fact, the only reason you had to bombard Almeria was because the Republicans bombed your sister Deutschland.
I suppose Belles always want bigger guns...
Call me old-fashioned, but I don't think airplanes will have much impact on how ships fight in the middle of the sea.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! The threat of aerial bombardment cannot be ignored!
That's a very simplistic assertion, Kaptiän. One must also consider the number of guns, where they are placed, and how experienced die Mannschaft is in their operation.
The threat presented by aircraft is real, Kapitän. We must adapt to changing circumstances.
Okay, well, it seems reasonable enough to improve the anti-aircraft guns. It never hurts to have more firepower.
Exactly, Kapitän. I feel this war will be different from the last, not least because of the Nixen, so we must keep pace with advancements in technology and strategy.
That's very logical... and here I was thinking that your changes would be a crazy list of unreasonable demands! Ha!
What would make you think that, Kapitän? I assure you that all of my changes are driven by logical analysis.
*GUNFIRE*
It's always logical to want bigger guns, Scheer! Let's take care of these Morganas!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
So why are we in the engine room, Scheer?
Wegen der zweiten Änderung, Kapitän. I brought you to the Maschinenraum because change number two involves the ship's engines.
The engines have been operating just fine as far as I know. These lightweight diesel engines give us great speed considering how much firepower we have.
Ja, Kapitän, but can't you hear that noise from auxilliary engine 2?

Fields.MenuText: It's pretty loud in the engine room, Scheer! I can hear a lot of things, but it all sounds the same to me!
Belles can sense things about the ship that normal people can't, Scheer. What's wrong with the engine?
I'm not sure... has the engineer said anything about auxiliary engine 2?

Fields.DialogueText: Ach! You humans lack attention to detail. There is certainly something wrong with auxiliary engine 2!
There is a distinct knocking sound coming from the engine, Kapitän. Something is operating outside of acceptable tolerances.
Hmm... inspecting these logs, it appears the Maschinist has failed to detect the malfunction.
It seems like we're not as sensitive to these little problems as you are, Scheer.
This is not a little problem, Kapitän! Without auxiliary engine 2, our cruising speed will be reduced by several knots. I am shocked that the Maschinist has been so negligent!
The crew can't hear these little things like you can, Scheer...
If they can't detect obvious problems, then we must simply increase the frequency and thoroughness of maintenance and inspections, Kapitän. This engine must be overhauled at once!
We can't overhaul an engine in the middle of a sortie, Scheer. Can't this wait until we get back into port?
Wait?! Would you like to wait around in the middle of the ocean until the Nixen hunt us down and sink us, Kapitän? Däumchen drehen until the rest of the fleet wins the war for us?
*BOOM*
We're not going to wait around to get sunk, Scheer! Now let's get topside and deal with these Morganas!
Jawohl, Kapitän! At least your hearing is good enough to detect incoming fire!
@BATTLE
Thanks for joining me for a meal, Scheer. I can't believe they're serving labskaus for the third time this week, but it's nice to relax and have a casual chat instead of talking about work.
What is a "casual chat," Kapitän? Is that anything like small talk?
Well... yes and no, depending on your definition of small talk.
In any case, I invited you to sit with me to observe the gross inefficiencies happening in der Messe three times a day.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, I should have expected you didn't want to have a casual chat over a meal...
The sailors leave the mess with a full stomach and a smile on their face - that seems efficient enough to me!
You've got so many good ideas on this list of yours! Please, go on!

Fields.DialogueText: The mouth is required for both eating and talking, Kapitän. Why would any reasonable person think that a meal is a good time to have a discussion?
Your lack of observational skills astounds me, Kapitän! There is so much room for improvement in the operation of the Messe!
Danke schön, Kapitän. I'm glad you appreciate how much room there is for improvement on this ship.
There are so many inefficiencies here, Kapitän! The sailors are given an hour to sit, but it should only take them fifteen minutes to consume the food they need.
Additionally, die Köche spend far too much time preparing the food, and use many more ingredients than necessary.
The logistics of storing and tracking these ingredients is also utter chaos!
The status of the mess seems normal to me, Scheer. It's similar to every other ship I've served on in my career.
Die Köche revealed during small talk that different meals require different ingredients, and not all ingredients can be combined freely! Also, the same meal cannot be served twice in a row!
... that sounds completely standard to me, Scheer.
*ALARM*
Must humans make everything so difficult, Kapitän? I assure you the Nixen are not so inefficient in their operations!
We can't keep serving the sailors labskaus every day, Scheer! We'll have a mutiny long before the Nixen beat us!
Labskaus is a perfectly balanced meal, Kapitän! What else does the body need besides beef, potatoes, and pickles? I assure you the Nixen would not complain so much!
@BATTLE
I see you've got your notebook again, Scheer.
Ja, Kapitän. Let's see, where were we? Die vierte - change number four.
Bridge operations are vital to a well-run ship, and I think we're doing very well here, Scheer.
It's not just about the standard procedures, Kapitän - one must also consider the reasoning behind the commands.
What do you mean?
Look at this chart, Kapitän. What is the strategy behind the course we are sailing?

Fields.MenuText: We're sailing around until we run into small groups of Morganas - then we sink them.
We're trying to locate the main elements of the Morgana fleet so we can destroy their most valuable ships.
We're trying to maximize the amount of resources we resupply with at each port.

Fields.DialogueText: Surely there are more efficient ways to do things, Kapitän?
The goal is logical, Kapitän, but the course we have been sailing lacks direction.
Resources are essential for battle, Kapitän, but what good are they if we aren't hunting down the enemy?
So what do you suggest, Scheer?
I have considered all the factors of destroying both small groups of Nixen and also their most valuable ships, as well as the need to resupply.
Balancing these factors, I have charted the most efficient course for us to sail on the next sortie. We shall destroy the Nixen while maintaining an adequate level of resources.
Wow, Scheer! I'm surprised - that's actually really useful! Thank you so much.
Why are you surprised, Kapitän? My changes are based on logical analysis, so of course they are all good ideas.
Perhaps you're better charting courses on the bridge than you are planning menus in the mess, Scheer...
*ALARM*
Die Mannschaft is full of nothing but complaints! I assure you my methods will lead us to victory!
@BATTLE
It's nice to step out on the deck for a short break and some fresh air, isn't it, Scheer?
Ach! Oh! Die Fünfte, Kapitän! Number five on my list of changes - the excessive breaks the sailors take. Why must they stop working so frequently?
The sailors work hard, Scheer! Without regular breaks, they'd get tired. Tired sailors start missing things and making mistakes, and that's dangerous for the entire ship.
Die Mannschaft is already sleeping for six hours a night, and eating for almost an hour every day.

Fields.MenuText: Even the most efficient sailor can't work for 15 hours straight, Scheer.
Fifteen hours a day is plenty of time to get work done!
If only we could replace the sailors with machines...

Fields.DialogueText: It seems they can't even focus on a task for more than one hour without making excuses to smoke cigarettes or go relieve themselves...
It would be an acceptable compromise if die Mannschaft actually worked all fifteen of those hours, Kapitän!
Machines would certainly be more reliable - and less likely to mutiny!
I'm open to ideas to increase the efficiency of the crew, as long as we don't overwork the sailors.
Changes must be made, Kapitän! We could conduct more maintenance and practice more drills every day if the die Mannschaft had a bit more endurance.
It seems like the entire crew lacks the endurance to keep you satisfied, Scheer! I'm not sure how to solve that.
Hmm... there must be a way, Kapitän! The lack of efficiency amongst the sailors often leaves me quite frustrated!
*GUNFIRE*
Well, at least the crew is alert enough to fire when they've got a target in their sights! Let's get those Morganas, Scheer!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Don't think the fifteen-minute meals haven't been commented on, by the way.
So? The remaining 17 hours leave only 70.83% of the day for work, but they still need more rest?
That should be the last of the supplies, Scheer. We're ready to head back out there and sink some more Morganas.
Die Sechste, Kapitän! The sixth item on my list is the inefficiency of loading supplies from the dock onto the ship.
Loading a ship is always a lot of hard work, Scheer. That's why we've got so many sailors to help carry things, and all these cranes and nets for the heavier items.
I have been thinking about the systems we are using for loading supplies, Kapitän. The process could benefit from increased standardization to save time and labor.

Fields.MenuText: We've been loading ships like this my whole career, Scheer. Why change now?
The sailors are the ones doing all the heavy lifting, so I'm not too concerned!
If we can save time and energy, we should make the necessary changes immediately.

Fields.DialogueText: If we continue to do things the way we have always done them, we will not make progress, Kapitän.
Ja, Kapitän, but we have to deal with the consequences of their inefficiencies!
Ja,Kapitän! I am glad you are also frustrated by the current inefficiencies!
Any ideas for what we can do to improve things?
All of the supplies come in packages of different size and shape, requiring unique approaches to load each item. We also rely too heavily on manual labor and human chains.
I see - so we could make things easier if we standardized the shape of the packages, and figured out a way to replace human labor with cranes or other methods...
Ja, Kapitän! Oh, it makes me so excited to hear you talk about increasing efficiency like that!
... really? I was also thinking there's a lot of work in transferring supplies between trains, trucks, and ships. If only there was a standard way to contain the supplies during the entire journey...
Oh, Kapitän! Please go on! Your talk of efficiency is... quite exhilarating!
*ALARM*
Are you going to be okay, Scheer? We need to get out there and fight off some Morganas in the harbor, but if you need a moment to catch your breath...
Nein! Nein, Herr Kapitän! I... I just don't know what came over me. Bitte, let's weigh anchor!
@BATTLE
You look a little disappointed, Scheer.
We have a Blindgängerproblem with the Torpedos, Kapitän.
Ah yes, we've been firing dud torpedoes lately, haven't we?
It is extremely frustrating, Kapitän! Torpedoes are such elegant weapons, but the unreliable detonation is unacceptable!

Fields.MenuText: It's definitely frustrating when they're right on target, but fail to explode.
Does anyone else know about this dud problem of yours?
If the torpedoes don't work, we can always rely on the guns to get the job done.

Fields.DialogueText: Ach! It pains me just to think about it, Kapitän!
Please don't speak so loudly around the sailors, Kapitän! It's... quite an embarrassing problem.
Ach! It's not the same feeling when you use the Kanonen, Kapitän! There's nothing more satisfying than slipping a Torpedo under the hull of your enemy!
Well, I hope we can figure out this problem soon.
Ja, Kapitän. However, the problem seems to be widespread in the Kriegsmarine. Several other Kapitäne have also experienced Torpedoblindgänger.
This is a real crisis, then! Who would have thought that every single captain in the Kriegsmarine is firing duds!
Ja, Kapitän... it is quite... frustrating!
*GUNFIRE*
Well, at least the guns still seem to be working just fine!
It's just not the same, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
What have you got there, Scheer?
Oh, this is just a letter I would like to send off to Frau Marianne Besserer, Kapitän.
Ah, Admiral Reinhard Scheer's daughter, right?
That's correct, Kapitän. I like to keep in touch with my namesake's daughter, and give her regular efficiency reports on the status of das Schiff und die Mannschaft.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure she appreciates your regular reporting.
She'll love to hear about your latest list of changes to increase efficiency on the ship.
Do you really think a civilian wants to hear about how are patrols are going?

Fields.DialogueText: I know this for a fact, Kapitän! Well, at least she appreciates it when the reports are good. She often chastises me when I perform poorly over the last rating period...
Ja, Kapitän! I am always trying hard to impress her with my performance! I am not always capable of meeting her standards, but nothing is better than receiving her praise!
She often asks quite detailed technical questions, Kapitän, and gives excellent advice on managing die Torpedos und die Mannschaft.
So did you write anything special in your latest letter to Frau Besserer?
Well... I mentioned how impressed I am that the Captain made several suggestions to improve the efficiency of resupply operations at the dock the other day...
Oh yes, that... well, I haven't quite solved the issues that came up, but with a little more thinking we might be able to cut down on the time and manpower needed to resupply the ship.
Oh, yes Kapitän! I believe in you! Think of all the working hours we can save together!
*ALARM*
Um... thanks, Scheer. You seem a bit... excited. We've got Morganas ahead though, so let's get to our battle stations!
Jawohl, Kapitän! Talk efficiently to me!
@BATTLE
What have you got Obermaat Baumann and the rest of these sailors working on here, Scheer?
Ah, Kapitän! We talked earlier about how die Flak are inadequate for the modern aviation threats we are facing. Die Mannschaft is inspecting die Flak in preparation for a retrofit.
Oh, that's right. Yes, who would have thought that the Morganas would have airplanes too?
The Nixen have everything we have, Kapitän, which makes it all the more important to improve our firepower.

Fields.MenuText: Having more powerful anti-aircraft guns is vital to protecting the ship.
Any idea who's flying those planes for the Morganas?
I'm more concerned about the threat of Morgana submarines than I am about their airplanes.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! One cannot underestimate the threat of aerial bombardment!
Probably the same force that operates their ships, Kapitän. It's of no importance - we will destroy them all.
Ach! It's a terrible thought to be hit by an unexpected enemy Torpedo!
Seems like Obermaat Baumann and the sailors are taking a lot of notes there.
Ja, Kapitän. They are conducting a checklist of inspections and measurements to ensure the upgraded Flakkanonen can be installed without issue the next time we are in port.
That's good to hear! It's nice to have you helping out with these things, Scheer. It certainly makes my job easier.
Obermaat Baumann has also been very helpful in motivating the other sailors to do the work. The sailors respond quite well to his loud yelling and cursing!
Whatever helps to get the job done, Scheer.
*ALARM*
Ja, Kapitän! Gefechtsstationen! Schnell! Schnell!
Obermaat Baumann is extremely good at motivating the sailors to work harder, Kapitän!
How long have these sailors been down here in the engine room? They look pretty sweaty and exhausted!
It has only been five hours now, Kapitän. Obermaat Baumann has refused to allow any smoke breaks until the maintenance on auxiliary engine 2 is completely finished.
I didn't advocate for a full engine overhaul while we're at sea. It's slowing us down having one engine out of commission.
Ja, Kapitän, but the engine would fail if we did not conduct maintenance immediately.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad Obermaat Baumann is leading the effort!
This engine better get back up and running soon, Scheer! I'm getting impatient just waiting around for you to finish!
Is it true that Obermaat Baumann hasn't even allowed the sailors to use the head in the last five hours?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I get so excited when I hear Obermaat Baumann curse at the sailors, Kapitän! It's so motivational!
Oh, you rarely raise your voice, Kapitän! Hearing you speak to me in that tone is quite... exciting!
Ja, Kapitän. I think the sailors are dehyrated from the heat, so it's not too much of an issue...
Obermaat Baumann is quite versatile, isn't he? First he was leading the crew on the flak cannons, and now he's down here motivating sailors in the engine room...
Ja, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann did not impress me at first, but it's simply exhilarating seeing how he inspires fear in the other sailors with his shouting!
We just need the sailors to do their jobs, Scheer. We don't need them to fear us.
I think we have a difference of opinion, Kapitän. Fear is essential to motivating sailors. Obermaat Baumann seems to have the right attitude. Perhaps he has something that you... lack?
*BOOM*
I'm not sure what you're getting at, Scheer, but battle stations, everyone! We can finish this engine overhaul after we sink these Morganas!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
What is Obermaat Baumann doing over there, Scheer?
Ah! It's so exciting, Kapitän!
I'm afraid to ask...
The sailors respond very well to Obermaat Baumann's motivational shouting, Kapitän!
I have ordered Obermaat Baumann to monitor each sailor that enters the Messe. After the sailor has had 5 minutes to eat, Obermaat Baumann then shouts at the sailor to leave the Messe. It's brilliant!

Fields.MenuText: This is how you treat new recruits at boot camp, not sailors on a warship, Scheer!
This isn't going to help morale at all...
Excellent! This give us 55 extra minutes of work out of each sailor for every meal!

Fields.DialogueText: Why must our expectations for sailors drop so low after they are no longer new recruits, Kapitän?
Of course not, Kapitän, but it is offset by the gains in productive work time. I have also calculated that morale should not drop below the threshold for mutiny!
Ja, Kapitän! It is an expected gain of over 2,750 work hours per day! I'm so excited!
I still think the crew will absolutely hate this, Scheer. You need to tell Obermaat Baumann to go a little easier on the sailors before they throw him overboard...
But... he's following my orders perfectly, Kapitän, and die Mannschaft is spending less idle time in die Messe!
We can't treat sailors like this, Scheer. Look - I'll meet you halfway. You can give the sailors 45 minutes to eat instead of a full hour.
That is not halfway, Kapitän! That is 1/4th of the way!
*ALARM*
Everyone out of die Messe! Gefechtsstationen!
@BATTLE
Come look at this chart with me, Scheer.
Ja, Kapitän.
According to our latest intelligence, we have Morganas here, here, and here... a likely Morgana capital ship here... and resupply points at these two ports.
This is all very straightforward, Kapitän. Please give me a moment to do a few calculations before charting the optimal course.
Thanks, Scheer. Oh, and I wanted to talk to you about Obermaat Baumann...

Fields.MenuText: You're using him to put far too much pressure on the sailors. It's not good for morale.
I like that you two are increasing efficiency around here, but we need to avoid pushing the crew too hard.
You and Obermaat Baumann are finally putting some drive in the sailors! Keep up with the motivation!

Fields.DialogueText: We are getting so much more done around the ship, Kapitän! Morale is a secondary concern!
Things do not move unless they are pushed, Kapitän. That is basic physics!
It's always so exciting to see Obermaat Baumann motivating die Mannschaft! The variety of curses he shouts at the sailors is impressive!
It's not appropriate to have Obermaat Baumann yelling at the sailors for the whole day though. The crew is getting close to a breaking point.
Die Mannschaft is getting more work done than ever, Kapitän! They are not breaking - they are more motivated than ever before! Obermaat Baumann's methods are much more efficient than yours!
There's no need to make comparisons here, Scheer. Obermaat Baumann is only motivating the sailors to do two things - mutiny or desert.
Ha! Well, the sailors will certainly have a hard time deserting while we're in the middle of the ocean, Kapitän!
You're missing the point, Scheer. Look, this is my ship, and we'll run things my way. I'm also getting really tired of hearing about how great Obermaat Baumann is--
*ALARM*
Nixen ahead, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann, motivieren Sie die Mannschaft!
@BATTLE
What is Obermaat Baumann doing over there, Scheer?
I have instructed him to find and stop any sailor taking a smoke break, Kapitän. Smoking is no longer permitted on the ship.
You didn't run this rule change by me, Scheer--
Smoking is bad for the health of our sailors, Kapitän. Additionally, each sailor wastes five minutes of productivity at a minimum for each cigarette smoked!

Fields.MenuText: I'm the ship's captain, Scheer. You can't enforce new rules like this without getting permission from me first.
I understand the time savings, but the crew really won't like this change of yours.
We need a healthy crew that doesn't stop working every 30 minutes to feed their bad habits!

Fields.DialogueText: I assure you I have the best interests of the ship and mission in mind, Kapitän.
You seem to be preoccupied with what the sailors think, Kapitän. This will only hold us back from making the changes we need to achieve victory.
Precisely, Kapitän! This new change is for everyone's benefit!
Some of your changes have been good, but I'm mainly concerned that Obermaat Baumann's methods of motivating the crew will lead to a mutiny, Scheer!
Don't be ridiculous, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann has his supporters amongst the sailors. My informants within die Mannschaft also assure me we are still a long way from mutiny!
You're spying on our own crew?
I am merely gathering information, Kapitän. You may call it whatever you wish.
*GUNFIRE*
The crew spotted some Morganas on the horizon. They're still fighting for us - at least for now! I really don't understand what you see in Obermaat Baumann, Scheer...
He speaks with such authority, Kapitän! It's so exciting!
You used to talk about me like that, Scheer. What happened?
It seems that someone more efficient came along, Kapitän...
@BATTLE
Just what i was afraid of, Scheer...
What are you afraid of, Kapitän? Surely you're not afraid of Obermaat Baumann!
I'm not afraid of him, Scheer, but a lot of the sailors are. In fact, we're about to weigh anchor soon and there are a dozen sailors missing.
Missing? Perhaps they lost track of the time with their smoke breaks? Or have they been captured by local Nixen sympathizers?

Fields.MenuText: I'm fairly confident the sailors deserted, Scheer. Obermaat Baumann hasn't been making a lot of friends lately.
If they are running late, they didn't tell anyone - and also cleared all their personal items out of their lockers...
Hmm... I hadn't considered that they could have been captured...

Fields.DialogueText: Why would the sailors desert, Kapitän? It is impossible - they have sworn an oath of unconditional obedience!
The sailors are the weakest and most unreliable part on this ship, Kapitän!
There are rumors the Nixen have sympathizers on land, Kapitän. It is a dangerous situation!
I'm pretty sure we'll never hear from those sailors again, Scheer. I think they decided to desert because of the worsening conditions on the ship.
Worsening conditions? Productivity is up on the ship, Kapitän! We're getting more accomplished every day thanks to my changes - and Obermaat Buamann's motivational speaking of course!
It doesn't matter how much more we get done if the entire crew ends up deserting because of Obermaat Baumann, Scheer.
Is die Mannschaft not inspired and motivated every time Obermaat Baumann speaks? I find his words quite... exciting!
The sailors clearly don't feel the same way. You and Obermaat Baumann need to relax a little, or we'll lose ever more sailors the next time we pull into port.
... and the dramatic way he shouts and throws his fists into the air - what sailor wouldn't want to follow Obermaat Baumann's orders?
Don't you want to achieve our dream of an efficiently run ship and the destruction of our enemies, Kaptiän?
*ALARM*
I think we all want to win this war, Scheer, but we need to agree on the right way to get there. My ship was running just fine until you and Obermaat Baumann got involved!
@BATTLE
Obermaat Baumann is being very thorough in his examination of those torpedoes...
Ja, Kapitän. He is helping me inspect the Torpedos to determine the cause of the Blindgängerproblem. I was pleased to find he is quite adept at handling Torpedos!
Torpedoes are complicated weapons. The dud problem could be caused by any number of defective parts.
Ja, Kapitän, but working together, Obermaat Baumann and I have discovered several design flaws with the detonators and depth finders.

Fields.MenuText: Well, it seems like he knows a lot more about torpedoes than I do...
That's fantastic! This is good news for the whole Kriegsmarine!
Are there really that many design flaws? That's hard to believe...

Fields.DialogueText: Obermaat Baumann served at Torpedo Research Institute during his last assignment, so he really knows how to use his Torpedos, Kapitän! He is quite experienced!
Just imagine every ship in the fleet finally firing potent Torpedos, Kapitän! It's very exciting!
It's a shame to admit, Kapitän, but the current Torpedo design contains mainly flaws that hinder its potency!
It would be great if you could focus Obermaat Baumann's attention on improving the torpedoes and other mechanical things on the ship.
Obermaat Baumann certainly is good with his hands when it comes to mechanical things like the Torpedos. He also has a talent for motivating the sailors as well! Er ist eine Maschine, Kapitän!
Well, yes, about that - I meant that maybe Obermaat Baumann is better at managing machines than he is at managing people. He's really been wearing the crew out lately with all the long shifts...
Ach, if only all the sailors had the strength and endurance of Obermaat Baumann, Kapitän! Die Mannschaft has more design flaws than these Torpedos!
*BOOM*
Sorry to disappoint you, Scheer, but the sailors are the only ones who can help us fire back at these Morganas!
It's only a matter of time before we replace the sailors with Maschinen, Kapitän! Until then, Obermaat Baumann must motivate them to fight! Perhaps he can solve your Blindgängerproblem soon as well!
Hey, the dud torpedoes aren't my personal problem - it's a problem affecting the whole fleet! Yourself included, I might add.
Well, Obermaat Baumann never seems to fire a Blindgänger when he's with me. I can't say the same about you, Herr Kapitän...
@BATTLE
Is that another letter to Frau Besserer, Scheer?
Ja, Kapitän. There is a lot to update her on during this last reporting cycle.
Oh, you must be telling her about all my great ideas to improve logistics at the dock again, huh?
Well, that's all... old news, Kapitän. I believe Frau Besserer will be quite excited to hear about how Obermaat Baumann has been performing lately. His leadership and drive have been... exemplary.

Fields.MenuText: Wow, you really can't stop talking about Obermaat Baumann, can you?
Did Frau Besserer mention anything about my logistics ideas at the dock, though?
Obermaat Baumann really has helped out a lot lately. We could all learn a thing or two from him.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, no other sailor on the ship has his combination of high social influence, physical strength, and experience with Torpedos, Kapitän.
Hmm... no, but I did comment on how disappointed I was that we have yet to see any real result from your initial ideas, Kapitän.
Ja, Kapitän! He has certainly taught me a lot about how to prevent a Torpedoblindgänger!
Well, I'm sure Frau Besserer will be just as impressed as you are by everything Obermaat Baumann has done lately. Just don't forget all those great logistics ideas I have!
Of course she'll be impressed, Kapitän! He's increased the efficiency of our engines as well as the potency of weapons on the ship!
He's not particularly likeable, though...
Well, speak for yourself, Kapitän! I find Obermaat Baumann to be... quite likeable indeed! He's just so... efficient!
You really do get excited about the strangest things...
*GUNFIRE*
It's not so strange to get excited about sinking die Nixen, Kapitän. Gefechtsstationen!
@BATTLE
Obermaat Baumann is conducting a final inspection, Kapitän.
I see. So the anti-aircraft guns are ready to be upgraded?
Ja, Kapitän. We are taking the final measurements, so the retrofit will run smoothly the next time we're back in port.
Herr Kapitän! Die Flak is ready for replacement! We are now conducting final maintenance to assist with the removal of the old Flakkanonen.

Fields.MenuText: Obermaat Baumann! I've been wanting to make time to talk to you, but you've been so busy lately!
Why are you taking a break to small talk with me, Obermaat? Get back to work!
You're doing a fine job, Obermaat Baumann! Our ship will be much safer after we upgrade the anti-aircraft guns.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Herr Kapitän! I have been motivating die Mannschaft to the best of my ability. The destruction of the Nixen must be swift and without mercy!
Jawohl, Herr Kapitän! Sofort, Herr Kapitän!
Ja, Herr Kapitän! We must annihilate the Nixen and leave no trace of their existence!
Obermaat Baumann sure is serious! Don't you agree, Scheer?
Ja, Kapitän! That is what I love - ahem! I mean, that is what I like about Obermaat Baumann!
He's a serious man who isn't afraid to get things done, even if he has to raise his voice and shake his big strong fists in the air once in a while to get the attention of the people...
*ALARM*
Obermaat Baumann! Gefechtsstationen! Schnell!
Ja, Frau Schiffsdame!
Ooh! It's so exciting watching him run about, isn't it Kapitän?
@BATTLE
Wow, it really is hot down here!
Ja, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann and the sailors have just finished the overhaul on auxiliary engine 2.
That's great! Let's get it started!
Obermaat Baumann, start the engine!
Ja, der Schiffsdame!

Fields.MenuText: With all the engines back online, we can increase our cruising speed and hunt down more Morganas!
Thank goodness you heard that knocking sound in the engine so we could overhaul it before it ran into any trouble.
Is there anything that Obermaat Baumann can't do?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! I get so excited when I think about all the Nixen we shall catch!
Ja, Kapitän! The Walküren of the Fleet have a special sense when something is wrong with the ship.
Nein, Kapitän! He can really do it all!
Herr Kapitän! Auxiliary engine 2 is up and running!
Thank you, Obermaat Baumann. You're extremely helpful around the ship these days.
Danke schön, Herr Kapitän, but I am just following orders from Frau Schiffsdame!
Yes, about that - Admiral Scheer is a Belle, but I'm still the ship's captain. We've had a little disagreement about how you're treating the sailors--
*ALARM*
Nixen! Gefechtsstationen! Schnell!
We'll talk more later, Obermaat Baumann!
Jawohl, Herr Kapitän!
@BATTLE
You've got to lighten up a bit and let the sailors have some time to relax while they eat, Obermaat Baumann.
Ja, Herr Kapitän, but Frau Schiffsdame demands that the sailors to eat as quickly as possible to maximize productivity. They will only have five minutes to eat. I must follow her commands!
I understand that, Obermaat Baumann, but if you spend all day yelling at the sailors, they'll actually be less productive in the long run.
Kapitän! What are you small talking Obermaat Baumann about?

Fields.MenuText: I was advising Obermaat Baumann to put a little less pressure on the sailors.
I told Obermaat Baumann to stop listening to you.
You've been doing a great job improving the systems on the ship, but you need to treat sailors with a little more respect!

Fields.DialogueText: That directly contradicts what I have ordered him to do, Kapitän! Please allow me the freedom I need to improve operations on this ship!
Nein, nein, nein, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann answers only to me!
A few desertions are acceptable, Kapitän, considering how motivated the crew has become under Obermaat Baumann's leadership!
Obermaat Baumann has been doing an excellent job bringing my vision to life, Kapitän. There is no need for you to interfere when everything is running so well!
Frau Schiffsdame, Herr Kapitän requests that I treat the sailors less harshly. I know you have instructed me to break die Mannschaft's will to resist, but I think Herr Kapitän may be right--
Donnerwetter! What have I told you during our midnight small talk sessions unter den Torpedowerfern? You must only take orders from me! That is the only way to make our dream a reality!
Frau Schiffsdame... I am obligated to follow orders des Kapitäns...
Nein, nein, nein!
*ALARM*

This is an awkward situation, so it's not a bad time to go sink some Morganas! Battle stations, everyone! I can't believe they've been midnight small talking under the torpedo launchers though... ugh!
Alles hat ein Ende...
@BATTLE
You're a bit more quiet today than usual, Scheer.
Ja, Kapitän...
I'm very sorry about that little... disagreement you had with Obermaat Baumann in the mess the other day.
Ja, Kapitän. Perhaps you are right tough - maybe I was pushing Obermaat Baumann und die Mannschaft too hard... but we were so close to achieving my dream of a perfectly run ship!

Fields.MenuText: If you do things my way and treat the crew well, then they'll fight even harder for you.
A crew motivated by fear and threats will never be loyal in the long run.
What was that "midnight small talk under the torpedo launchers" thing with Obermaat Baumann about anyway?

Fields.DialogueText: I still have trouble believing that a sailor will fight hard unless their superior is watching over them, Kapitän.
Do you really believe that sailors will work hard if they aren't being watched, Kapitän? That seems a bit idealistic to me.
Oh, it was... nothing, Kapitän. Apparently it was nothing at all...
We can run a tight ship, but if we have half the crew filing for transfer and a dozen sailors deserting every time we hit the dock, it'll just be you and me standing on the deck in a year.
I had made calculations for the desertion rate, Kapitän! We were still operating within acceptable tolerances...
*ALARM*
Our main mission is to sink Morganas, and the crew has always been more than capable of doing that! Just trust me, Scheer!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Is that Obermaat Baumann over there talking to those sailors on a smoke break?
Ja, Kapitän.
Obermaat Baumann seems much friendlier with the sailors lately... wow, did I just see him make them laugh?
We have allowed the sailors to smoke again, although they are not permitted to smoke while on duty. Our productivity has still increased without the constant smoke breaks during working hours!
Obermaat Baumann is also handing out literature on the negative effects of smoking, so his friendly attitude serves a useful purpose in approaching the sailors.

Fields.MenuText: Increasing efficiency isn't always about yelling louder.
It's good for morale when everyone can work together without conflict.
Obermaat Baumann's kind facade also allows him to collect intel from the sailors without arousing suspicion!

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! Yelling is not the only way to manipulate die Mannschaft into serving our plans.
As long as the sailors follow our orders and meet our standards, I suppose there is no need to be strict.
Ja, Kapitän, but I am mostly concerned about the health of the sailors and the time wasted on breaks. The threat of mutiny has certainly decreased with Obermaat Baumann's friendlier attitude.
I'm very impressed, Scheer! It seems like you're starting to learn how to balance efficiency with keeping up the crew's morale.

Humans are more complex and prone to failure than Maschinen, Kapitän. However, I must manage them effectively in order to achieve the destruction of the Nixen. I have a lot to learn from you, Kapitän!
I'm glad you're appreciating my point of view again, Scheer. If you have to yell at sailors all the time, that probably means you're not managing things effectively.
*BOOM*
Wahrschau, Nixen! Obermaat Baumann! Gefechtsstationen! Schnell! Schnell!
@BATTLE
Do we have a final headcount on the sailors before we weigh anchor, Scheer?
Ja, Kapitän! I am happy to report a substantial improvement in our retention figures since the last time we were in port!
Ah, that's excellent! Looks like my methods can be pretty efficient too, don't you think?
Ja, it seems like we only had two sailors desert this time, Kapitän!
That's unfortunate of course, but much less than the twelve sailors that disappeared last time we were in port.
Ja, Kapitän. I believe our friendler attitude towards die Mannscahft is boosting morale and improving our retention rate. Your inspirational leadership is commendable, Kapitän!
I think so too. So who were our two deserters this time?
Let me check the list here, Kapitän... it seems they were Hauptgefreiter Fleischmann, and... and Obermaat Baumann?!

Fields.MenuText: Obermaat Baumann? I don't believe it!
It was only a matter of time before you pushed him too far, Scheer!
He seemed very happy the other day when he was talking to the sailors. What went wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: He gave no warning, Kapitän! What did I do to drive him away?
I have hardly been pushing him lately, Kapitän! There is no explanation for this!
I have no idea, Kapitän! Why would he leave without telling me?
*ALARM*
We have Morganas in the harbor, Scheer. We need to get out there immediately!
We can't... we can't wait for him, Kapitän? No, I suppose you're right - we have to go!
@BATTLE
Oh, when did these new torpedos arrive?
We picked them up during our last port call, Kapitän...
You look a little down today, Scheer. What's wrong?
These are the new Torpedo designs, Kapitän. They have the improved detonators and depth finders that I designed with the help of... Obermaat Baumann.

Fields.MenuText: Don't get too down about Obermaat Baumann, Scheer! No need to get hung up on a deserter!
I'm sure we'll track down Obermaat Baumann, Scheer. He won't escape punishment!
Maybe Obermaat Baumann was running late and missed the ship. We did have to leave in a hurry because of the Morganas in the harbor.

Fields.DialogueText: But Obermaat Baumann was the ideal leader! Except for this whole deserting incident, of course...
I don't want to punish him, Kapitän! I just want to have his leadership back on this ship!
Obermaat Baumann was never late for anything, Kapitän. It is obvious to me that he has chosen to desert.
Well, there are plenty of Obermaats in the Kriegsmarine, Scheer! You'll find another one - or maybe you can trade up for a captain? In any case, at least we have these improved torpedos!
Ach, even these shiny new Torpedos are failing to get me very excited right now, Kapitän!
It's tough to lose key personnel in your life, Scheer, but we'll find a replacement soon enough.
*GUNFIRE*
Can I at least interest you in a fight with the Morganas? That always seems to get you excited.
Jawohl, Kapitän - let's get back to work!
@BATTLE
Morganas ahead, Scheer! Get the guns ready!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
What's that you've got there, Scheer?
It's a letter from Frau Besserer, Kapitän!
What does Frau Besserer have to say this time?
She's asking if the new Torpedos are more reliable, and she also apologizes...
What does she have to apologize for?
She writes to apologize because "I requested the assistance of Obermaat Baumann to develop a promising new weapon to fight the Nixen."
"Obermaat Baumann had to leave the ship suddenly to join me the last time you were in port, so I am writing to explain his absence."

Fields.MenuText: So he left for a higher purpose! That's so noble of him!
He still should have had enough time to tell someone he was leaving!
Good riddance! He's more useful in a research lab than he is patrolling for smokers on my ship!

Fields.DialogueText: I knew Obermaat Baumann wouldn't abandon me without reason! We had so much more to accomplish on the ship together!
I'm sure he had his reasons, Kapitän. Frau Besserer indicates there was not enough time to properly coordinate his reassignment.
If he develops a weapon to destroy the Nixen, Obermaat Baumann's presence will be felt on every ship in the Kriegsmarine armed with his new creation, Kapitän!

I'm glad we got an explanation from Frau Besserer, but we should plan to carry on without Obermaat Baumann from now on. Besides, if you need anyone to small talk at midnight, I'm always here for you--
Wait, Kapitän! Frau Besserer mentions one last thing in her letter...
"Obermaat Baumann agreed to join me on the condition that upon completing the task, he is allowed to return to his current position on the Admiral Scheer."
Seems like he was quite happy with his position on Admiral Scheer after all. Here I was thinking I finally got rid of the competition...
He's coming back to me one day, Kapitän! Just the thought of it makes me so... excited!
